isis.stitle: ELECTRICAL SYSTEM TROUBLESHOOTING GUIDE / 9200 9300 9400 MODELS BUILT AFTER JANUARY 1, 1995 - HEHR POWER SYSTEMS/POWERLINE ALTERNATORS USED ON EMERGENCY VEHICLES - DESCRIPTION

svcproc.title: DESCRIPTION
svcproc.para:
The Hehr Power Systems/Powerline 25 Series alternators (Refer to Figure 1
) are 14 volt, heavy-duty, belt-driven, air cooled units designed for clockwise operation (viewed from pulley end) in emergency vehicle diesel engine applications.

These units feature an internal voltage regulator, fully enclosed brushes, heavy-duty bearings, built-in rectifier assemblies with extra large heat sinks, a dynamically balanced rotor, and heavy-duty stator.

The alternators incorporate a large ball bearing at the drive end and a roller bearing at the slip ring end. The alternators have a two leg swivel mounting, one leg of which is equipped with a slideable bushing.
The brushes and voltage regulator are located in a waterproof housing and may be removed for replacement or inspection without dismantling the entire alternator.
Silicon diodes mounted in heat sinks convert alternating current from the delta wound stator into direct current.
On the Series 25-32 and -34 alternators, the positive and negative diode assemblies are mounted inside the alternator.
On the Series 25-35 and -41 alternators, the positive diode assemblies are mounted inside the alternator and the negative diode assemblies are mounted externally on the slip ring end.
The negative output terminal on the 25-35 and -41 alternator is internally grounded to the slip ring end (SRE) housing.
